Posts.Title: Hi, I'm new

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies, I hope you don't mind me butting in here but just wanted to share a few things with you. I've fortunately not had to have chemo on my c journey as I was caught very early, but I have had a hair loss issue for years. (Over 10 now)   I have posted quite a bit about hair on here and will try not to repeat what I have already said for those who read regularly, but firstly I want to say I know how distressing it can be having hair that really is a crowning glory, and knowing that temporarily you are going to lose it.  My hair was amazing (really thick cascades of shiny ringlets) and I would sometimes even be stopped in the street by people telling me what amazing hair I had.  For the first year of it's departure I did nothing but cry.  No-one could tell me why it was happening and there seemed no end to it.  I was heart breaking see the plughole literally blocked every morning and if I ran my hand through it masses of it would come away. Anyway - very long story short I tried for about 5 years to stop it using various different methods then gave up.  For the last 4 or so years I have just done my best to make it look thicker and healthier, which has involved using hair extentions some more permanent and others temporary (since my lumpectomy have just worn it on clips that I take in and out every day).   I probably have around a quarter of the hair I used to have.  I regularly used to wonder if I should cut it all off and try to find somewhere to have it made into some kind of wig so that at least I still had my own hair.  As I have some kind of condition that means my hair is all now different lengths this would never have worked for me, but the whole reason for me posting (apart from empathising with those who are struggling with the fact that they are losing their hair) is to suggest that anyone with good long hair should DEFINITELY cut it off and keep it as Lilybeth suggested.  Even if you decide never to do anything with it for personal use, you can actually get money for it (especially if its untreated hair) as there are plenty of people out there who will  buy it.  (People like me LOL)  Just put 'remy hair' into google and see what you get.  Lilybeth - salons like Lucinda Ellery in london use a very fine mesh to give people semi permanent hair replacement systems.  Maybe you could look into that way of utilising the hair on the comb? If anyone wants to add me as a friend and have a good old moan to a symathetic ear please add me as a friend.  Lots of luck and love and chins up.  And look foward to the day that you will see it starting to regrow:)  xx

Posts.Content: Hi all, Firstly, Annie as this was your thread I just wanted to say how much I feel for you every time I read your posts, and like a lot of people on here I just want to come to where ever you are and give you some really big but gentle hugs - as per your other thread I really do hope you get your appointment and what you need to get from the appointment very very soon xx With regard to the positive thinking arguement, I am definitely in agreement that whatever emotions are, they need to be authentic, as Sascha has said. Not sure if there have been any threads on this before, and apologies if I am repeating stuff that's been said, but one really useful therapy is CBT (cognitive behavioural thereapy).  The basics of CBT are about acknowleding the negative, but also searching for a positive to balance things out, and making sure that all  the thoughts that are causing the upset are actually facts and not just imaginings.  I believe that CBT is gaining a foothold within the NHS as a really effective way of treating lots of different issues, and when I googled CBT for cancer patients, without actually reading any of them, I could guess just from the number of articles the search produced that's it probably considered to be worthwhile.  There is a 'CBT for dummies' book if people aren't keen on actually going to a therapist, and for the sake of 12 quid or whatever it might cost, to get some balanced thinking going it has to be worth a shot.  Obviously just focusing on the negatives isn't partiularly healthy (there will always be a postive almost all situations, however small it may seem) but equally only thinking 'positive' thoughts can be equally as damaging.  I've heard it said (by a very wise therapist) that only using positive thoughts without acknowleding the negative is like having a birthday cake made of dog food covered with beautiful icing - it looks great on the outside but when you cut into it it's really not very good at all (Unless of course you are canine - Winston your terriers might like it!!)  Just my thoughts.  Love to all xx

Posts.Title: Parabens

Posts.Content: The most completely natural ranges I have used (back in the days when money wasn't such an issue) are Neals Yard and Organic Pharmacy.  Both are wonderul, but expensive (Neal's yard slightly cheaper).  Also good but equally expensive are Ren and Dr Hauschka.  I do remember asking about Origins in a department store, and I don't think their products are completely natural.   I'm not sure I believe or trust the cheaper ranges totally.  Can't quite put my finger on why - but just because a product says it's 'free from' this that and the other, I wonder what they are replacing it with.  SLS is a foaming agent - if the product still foams what's making it do that?  SLS is probably the cheapest foaming agent because it's in the cheapest products so if it is an SLS free product and is foaming what's making it do that?  Some of Organic Pharmacy's  products I have used do not foam.  I was disappointed with this but was told (admittedly by someone trying to sell more of it to me, so maybe I am just gullible!) that a totally natural product will not foam because there is nothing within nature that can be formulated to do this in quite the same way   There is a website called skindeep, but it's american so most of the products are not ones that we would always recognise but there are some of ours on there.  It has a lot of information on ingredients in each product and a hazard rating.  I remember having a surf around it a few years ago and being horrified to see Boots Botanical range come up as a high to medium hazard for some of the products in the range. http://www.ewg.org/skindeep/ I had a hair strand test done a few years ago (might be quackery but it was interesting at the time).  They can analyse exactly what toxic chemicals are present in your body.  The list was endless, but some of the more harmful ones found in my system were toluene (found in nail varnish, hair dyes, household products) benzopyrene (from exhaust fumes, open fires (have an open fire place but don't use it) and formaldehyde (fricking embalming fluid LOL) .  Interestingly I had the hair strand test done to determine the cause of my long term hair loss issue and having just googled to get the spellings, see that all three were linked to cancer. Hope I've not made anyone paranoid with the above, but I don't think it's just as easy buying a product that claims to be 'free from' this, that or the other.    I don't think ANY of these products or chemicals are harmful on their own, or they wouldn't get away with selling it (mind you - they still sell cigarettes still don't they) but maybe it's a cumulative effect that could be the issue.  Years and years of build up.   I'm just here thinking aloud really but hope I am not freaking anyone out! xx

Posts.Title: Tempting fate....ridiculous

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I joined because it seems like a really supportive group of people which would definitely help right now.  I got selected for a random mammgram (not sure if it's the same in every area but here they do them rountinely every 3 years for 50 and over and randomly select women from 47 to 50 (and 70 to 73 also I believe).  I got a recall for the mammgram but I wasn't worried as the nurse had explained that as it was my first they had nothing to compare it to, and they recall a higher percentage of people on their first.  So I was surprised and horrified when they showed me lots of little white dots of calcifcation on the xray.  They did a biospy that day and then a horrid 10 day wait for the results.  Inconclusive.  So they are going to do an op.  On the letter they copied me in on to my GP I have 'an area of atypical epithelial proliferation B3, set against a background of fibrocystic change'.  The surgeon (who was rather unpleasant, which is a shame as I am quite a sensitive soul) said they will put a wire in and take away an 18mm area for resection.  He is still telling me that there is a 3 in 10 chance only that it's malignant (which sounds like quite good odds to me) and I have been told by one of the other docs I have seen that if it is cancer it will be DCIS which doesn't seem to be the most serious of issues, but I have no idea really if I should be REALLY worried and preparing myself for the worst, or just hoping and praying that it's going to be benign.    I don't want to be too postive, because that's what I have done mostly up until now and then it's like a slap in the face when they are saying they still have a concern. Anyone who can offer me any ideas on the best mindset to try and acheive until I can get to two weeks after the op when I will finally know one way or the other would be much appreicated!  Thanks in advance of any responses:)
Posts.Title: New here, and not sure if I should be - yet.

Posts.Content: Yes echoing everyone else here - please don't go Sascha Rose....  You were one of the few to respond to me when I first joined here and didn't even have any kind of diagnosis.  I really appreciated that.  Your posts, opinions and journey (whether negative or postive) should continue to be heard and valued on here, as should everyone's.  I hate it when things go a bit 'tits up'  virtually (hope no-one takes offence to that - just trying to be a bit light hearted;).... if we were all together in a room face-to-face and able to see body language and interact properly I am sure there would be more chance for harmony and real support, but as it's virtual we just have to imagine that's how it would be if we were in a room all together xx
Posts.Title: Wishing everyone well and goodbye

Posts.Content: “Go as far as you can see.  When you get there you’ll be able to see further” Not sure if it’s a famous quote or not but it’s one that has helped me keep it all i perspective. xx
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Hi Louise, Saw the BC nurse for the very same thing today.   Had a lumpectomy on 17th July and a couple of days after the breast was 3 times bigger than normal and really painful.  Went back to see the BC nurse after a couple of days and she said it was probably a haematoma or seroma but nothing needed to be done. So six weeks down the track and had the first Onc appt last week and she told me to get it checked again by the BCN which I did today.  The looked at it on ultrasound and said yes it was a haematoma(it's massive - about 2 inches) and will eventually disperse.  The more it actually has healed the more prominent the lump has become but 3 peeps had a look today and no-one was concerned. I hope that reassures you in some way but I would still get someone to have a look to put your mind at rest, as people have suggested.  3 weeks is a lot of worrying time isn't it. Best wishes xx

Posts.Title: Hard lump under lumpectomy scar ?

Posts.Content: Hi Franoli, I just had a lumpectomy too but the day after it was very swollen and leaking.  I called the BCN and they asked me to come in to show them the day after that  - the swelling had reduced and she said the leakage was normal, but she insisted that they would rather reassure me than leave me worrying.  i would call and check with them if I were you. Best wishes xx
